John McClane.Action: Accepts his struggle to quit smoking, uses nicotine patches and says 'One day at a time.'
Shows frustration but does not take it out on the female clerk who refuses the car rental.
Keeps a low-key, simple room with no TV, minimal belongings visible.
Despite physical signs of wear (scrapes, burns, lacerations), he methodically prepares for the day, showing resilience and attention to detail (nicotine patch use).
Reacts with mild frustration or confusion ('What the hell, John.') indicating some self-awareness but also potential doubt.
Fails to secure a car rental due to insurance/system issues, showing a limitation in controlling external circumstances.
Offers a fifty-dollar tip to the shuttle driver despite the driver's sour attitude.
Responds with a resigned tone to the clerk about insurance being declined and requests a cab politely.
Agrees to buy extra insurance despite sensing a shake, showing adaptability.
Tries to call a cab but is hindered by external circumstances (taxi strike) and accepts the situation.
Offers a fifty-dollar tip to the shuttle driver to expedite his trip, demonstrating resourcefulness and confidence.
Acknowledges having a metal plate in his head and makes a self-deprecating joke about aging and pain.
Keeps calm during security check despite discomfort from metal detecting wand.
Attempts to reconnect with his son by offering a ride and trying to ease tension.
Appears awkward and unable to bridge emotional gulf with his son effectively.
Asks a cab driver for a ride despite the strike, using friendly and casual language ('Hey, man. Cabs are on strike. Could ya gimme a lift')
Teases his son Jack about screwing up ('Way to go, old man.'), but in a way that suggests familiarity rather than cruelty
Attempts to engage with Jack and show concern ('C’mon, Jack. A cup of coffee!') despite Jack’s refusal
Does not escalate the argument with Jack and instead tries to keep the peace or lighten the mood
Pushes quickly out of the exit and climbs stairs swiftly to the rail platform, showing urgency and physical capability.
Appears candid about past mistakes, saying 'Way to go, old man,' implying self-awareness and reflection.
Asks for a lift when cabs are on strike, indicating practical problem-solving.
Smokes a Nicorette tab instead of a cigarette, suggesting awareness about health or self-control.
Reacts to events as they unfold, shifting sight picture and preparing for next move, revealing attentiveness and readiness.
No explicit failures, hesitations, or illogical decisions evident in the excerpt; no negative indicators found.
Expertly keeps pace with his son while exiting the subway train nearly last in a crowded commuter situation.
Remains vigilant and observant in a busy public environment, such as noticing surroundings and people.
Says 'S'cuse me' politely when bumped by a hurried female.
Continues forward without retaliation or complaint when the hurried female ignores him and bumps him again.
Successfully uses a stolen laptop to access a backdoor into a secure system, displaying knowledge of Linux code and hacking skills to break into NorthEastern Gas and Electric's system.
Engages in quick, confident interaction with hacker 'Charlie Brown,' demonstrating situational awareness and control despite initial surprise.
Observes and interprets techno messages on multiple monitors at the electronics show, showing situational awareness and technical understanding.
Relies on external events and others (e.g. police assemblage) without taking immediate clear action himself.
On instinct, pushes Jack G aside and closes himself and the cop, trapping the cop's arm with the gun, then delivers an effective elbow shot to gain control of the weapon.
Issuing a clear and commanding order to the armed cop: 'YOU PUT THE GUN DOWN!'
Fires multiple shots decisively at Rooney, neutralizing the threat quickly.
Continuously chases after his son Jack G. despite exhaustion and physical strain.
Shouts at his son in frustration, declares he's done, showing impatience.
Attempts to communicate with his son even when Jack rejects him.
Dodges cars by running over roofs and trunks, quickly recovering and continuing the chase after Jack G.
Despite exhaustion and being winded, persists in chasing Jack G., showing determination and resilience.
Expresses frustration and admits being done ('THAT'S IT, I'M DONE!'), momentarily signaling a limit to his endurance.
Engages in a verbal confrontation with Jack G. and a bystander (Saturn driver) instead of focusing solely on pursuit.
Starts walking toward his son despite loud alarms, trying to hear him.
Shoots a final look at his son, a parting gesture that offers little hope.
Gets smacked with a rifle butt after a warning.
Propped and injured, remains involved in the situation without complaint or self-pity.
Interacts with others (Beebock, Panzarella) who recognize and even joke about his reputation, implying a sense of camaraderie.
No evidence of warmth-reducing behavior such as hostility or dismissiveness in the excerpt.
Is physically battered and dirty yet remains in control during a tense situation, showing resilience and presence of mind.
His reputation precedes him, as others acknowledge him as someone who survives despite being shot, indicating his toughness and capability.
Engages with Rooney calmly despite tension, refuses to escalate conflict verbally.
Responds with sarcasm and distrust towards law enforcement questioning.
References 'family values' in conversation, indicating concern for family.
Does not show aggression despite being handcuffed and under pressure.
Questions Rooney's accusations and does not immediately admit involvement, showing skepticism and some awareness.
Appears physically restrained and looks awful, suggesting he is currently impaired or not in control.
Responds sarcastically and somewhat dismissively to Rooney, not providing useful information.
Participates in the meeting with key government officials and contractors, paying close attention to their faces and details on screen, demonstrating awareness and focus.
Remains silent during technical explanations and lets others lead discussion, which might suggest lack of immediate input or expertise in digital security topics.
Questions the progression and seriousness of the cyberattack by asking what happens on Day 3, showing curiosity and engagement with the situation.
Expresses frustration or skepticism about homeland security funding effectiveness, indicating awareness but potential doubt about institutional competence.
Quickly scans information and assesses the situation regarding the Nuke Plant and power regulators.
Shows confidence and awareness by acknowledging challenges realistically through dialogue with others.
Relies on associates to provide important information, indicating effective teamwork.
Does not hesitate to consider offers or plans that might aid the mission, showing adaptability.
Shows regret for not spending time with his son and wants to make up for lost time.
Does not appear to care what happens to himself but cares about his son's future.
Accepts being cuffed and transported without resistance, showing compliance though internally conflicted.
Reflected upon by Rooney as a man who regrets past mistakes and cares deeply about his son's future, indicating emotional intelligence and motivation driving his decisions.
Jokes with his son about being 'uncool' and life changes, showing an attempt at light-hearted connection.
Shows resignation but engages with his son's feelings, indicating some emotional openness.
Expresses frustration and anger when telling his son to 'crawl back to your mom for all I care,' showing a harsh response in tension.
Confidently addresses his son Jack G with a mix of tough love and understanding, maintaining composure despite tense circumstances.
Physically clocks a Heavy Fed quickly and then refocuses on talking with his son, showing situational awareness and ability to act under pressure.
Uses humor and sarcasm to manage tension with Jack G, indicating emotional intelligence and social skill in stressful scenarios.
Uses a blunt and confrontational tone with his son when frustrated, which risks alienation rather than collaboration.
Engages in a hostile and confrontational argument with his son, showing sarcasm and defiance rather than empathy.
Maintains a tough, combative stance in a physical altercation without attempting to de-escalate.
Engages in a physical fight with Jack G and responds quickly by twisting and swinging his feet into the attacker’s mid-section, showing ability to handle confrontation.
Uses sarcastic and sharp retorts during verbal conflict, indicating confidence but not necessarily skill or intelligence related to a task.
Does not escalate the situation beyond necessary two-person fight, appears to keep control in a tense environment.
Commands the Transport Driver to keep driving despite danger, threatening to break someone's neck.
Secures and handcuffs the heavy fed and associates, showing control and responsibility.
Engages in banter with Jack G, showing humor and a friendly tone.
Performs an ugly headstand to wrap the chain around the floor and subdue the Heavy Fed, successfully disarming opponents and taking control.
Commands the Transport Driver to keep driving despite threat, showing confidence and quick decision-making under pressure.
Checks the rear window and assesses approaching threats (D.E.R.T. Helicopter), demonstrating situational awareness.
Uses road markers and signs to calculate current location precisely while engaging with Jack G, showing skilled navigation.
Responds to technical jargon and ideas from Jack G with a dismissive 'Swell....' indicating lack of full understanding but keeps conversation moving.

Takes control of the transport van from Jack G, puts on his seat belt, and maneuvers the van skillfully to evade pursuing sedans by driving hard right through a barrier and wooded area, causing the sedans to brake and not follow.
Instructs Jack G to put on his seat belt, demonstrating awareness of safety and control.
Confidently corrects Jack G's driving without hesitation, showing command and control in a stressful situation.
Immediately assists Jack G, calmly communicates with OnStar operator to get help after an accident.
Ignores distracting noises and focuses on helping and resolving the situation.
Uses a screwdriver skillfully to pry at the ignition switch to start the car despite difficult circumstances.
Ignores distracting noises (gunshots) to focus on the task at hand.
Takes control of the stalled car despite Jack G offering to drive, showing protective concern for someone recovering from a heart attack.
Crashes the security gate off its hinges while escaping quickly, showing reckless disregard for property in an emergency.
Throws the car in gear, hits the gas, and drives aggressively through a security gate to get to the hospital quickly.
Refuses to let Jack G drive despite his claim he can steal the car, citing his own skills and experience.
Accepts coffee kindly from the soccer mom and responds with dry humor.
Makes a sarcastic joke in response to soccer mom's whisper about Asperger's Syndrome.
Engages in lighthearted banter with the Whiz Kid about age and playfully responds to his questions.
Acknowledges urgency and need to move quickly when Jack G cannot find Charlie Brown, showing concern for the mission over casual delays.
Realizes the urgency of the situation and insists on moving quickly despite others being unsure or slow to act.
Interacts with a young 'whiz kid' and shows awareness of the situation by going back to his post after a brief questioning.
Appears to be relying on the 'whiz kid' and others to solve complicated problems instead of taking direct action himself.
Observes the chaotic situation calmly and logically, acknowledging the widespread disorder without losing composure.
Shows skepticism about trusting civilians involved in the situation (referring to Greg Pope as 'Wheelchair Guy' who might hand them over to the Feds).
Smiles and waves passively at the Gate Guard.
Gives an approving smirk after Jack G talks about hacking the IRS.
Recounts teaching Jack G to swim by throwing him in the water and telling him to paddle.
Blows through the gate in the Cadillac without an appointment but with confidence, signaling he knows how to handle the situation.
Smiles and waves passively at the gate guard, showing calmness and ease under minor pressure.
Uses casual banter with Jack G to recall past mentoring moments, indicating confidence and interpersonal skill.
Yells 'Don't shoot, don't shoot!!!' to prevent violence

Lightly mocks Jack G by saying 'I'm your dad. Embarrassing you comes with the job.'
Engages in a sarcastic tone with Pope about the situation instead of being hostile or rude.
Encourages teamwork by asking for help to delay a disaster and putting obstacles in the enemy's way.
Reassures Jack G by assigning roles in their plan and encourages him by calling him 'young stud' who 'always gets the girl.'
Directs and takes leadership in the plan, telling Jack G to shut up and listen.
Takes charge of the situation by assigning targets and initiating the plan confidently ('I'll go first, take out big guy in the track suit').
Successfully dispatches opponent quickly with a kick, showing physical skill and decisiveness.
Engages in close combat and struggles but continues fighting despite being overpowered and thrown through window.
Despite being entangled in an American flag and falling, McClane stirs and groans, indicating resilience and capacity to recover.
No indication of hesitation or confusion during fight; acts decisively and instructs partner to focus on his target.
Demonstrates confidence and leadership ('Be happy. Young stud always gets the girl.') which may boost morale.
Jokes with Roosevelt about steroids' worst part before violent confrontation.
Physically attacks Roosevelt aggressively and crashes car through glass to escape.
Pushes the car in reverse abruptly to escape danger, physically wrestles an opponent to avoid getting shot.
Collapses into the driver's seat appearing battered and exhausted, indicating physical vulnerability.
Engages physically and aggressively with Roosevelt to retrieve a weapon, taunts him playfully ('How's! That! Knee! Now!')

Grasps the steering wheel with both hands, maneuvers the stolen car through a chaotic environment including crashing through windows and obstacles, vaults off stairs, and maintains control despite physical attacks and pain.
Uses a sharp elbow strike to cause pain to an opponent and prevent them from seizing a weapon, showing tactical physical skill under pressure.
Despite being hit hard in the face, continues to focus on the goal and withstands pain without giving up.
His speech over the communication line comes out garbled and fragmented, indicating some difficulty in communication.
Throws the car into reverse and gas, smashing through walls to stop the threat, showing quick decisive action to protect others.
Asks Roosevelt where Pope is taking his son, indicates concern for others including Roosevelt’s children.
Says 'I flunked charm school', a self-deprecating comment showing some humility and humor.
Momentarily frozen near the helicopter, showing hesitation or momentary inaction under pressure.
Throws the car into reverse and gas, smashing through three walls and ripping up rows of luxury seats to stop the vehicle from crashing severely.
Comments 'I flunked charm school' after moments of tense action, showing a bit of self-deprecating humor but not undermining his situational control.
Reacting quickly to being choked and taking decisive control of the vehicle.
Speaks brusquely to Dispatch, expressing frustration and distrust.
Interacts with Jack G without hostility, engages in banter.
Steps out of the van and frees all the dogs, helping others who are abandoning their cars
Comments on human nature that people run when scared
Decides the fastest way to get to Jersey is by train despite a massive traffic jam.
Steps out with Jack G on the highway and frees the dogs in the panel van, showing quick adaptability.
Comments insightfully on human nature with 'People run when they're scared.'
Puts on the baseball cap given by Jack to protect his civil liberties, engages in light banter about divorce.
Instinctively takes up against an annoyed passenger who insults him.
Instinctively looks up to face the annoyed passenger at the right moment.
Uses a baseball cap to protect his identity from surveillance cameras.
Comments on his physical dishevelment (bruised, bloodied, needing a shave) showing self-awareness but no immediate action to improve it.
Jacks G tries to connect about family issues, McClane chooses not to answer and looks away quietly.

Straightens, rubs his face, looks out the window quietly instead of engaging in emotional discussion.

Does not engage in personal or emotional conversation, maintaining focus on the task.
Engages in playful, teasing banter imitating his son and reflecting on family memories; shows a half-smile and tries to connect with his son.
Frowns and appears somewhat distant despite the interaction with his son; does not fully embrace the warmth of the moment.
Prioritizes immediate action to escape danger over personal interactions, ordering the engineer and following strict safety measures.
Tells Jack G to do his thing and that he'll do his own, acknowledging the risk he takes on himself.
Encourages Jack G with 'Don't take any shit.' showing support and motivation.
Balks when asked to join, refusing to share danger directly, indicating some emotional distance or protectiveness.
Tells Jack G. to do his own thing while he handles his part, showing confidence in his unique skills.

Successfully taps into a computer station and gains access to the train's engine cab, indicating technical skill and resourcefulness.

Responds promptly to the ringing phone and engages with the adversary/Pope, showing situational awareness and readiness.

Displays casual confidence and quick wit in conversation with Pope, indicating comfort and assurance under pressure.

Continues to move forward despite heavy danger and is actively trying to save the situation on the train.
Lunges across the threshold into next car amidst heavy fire, slides and rolls to avoid bullets and gain entry.

No hesitation or apparent confusion when rockets aimed directly at him, showing quick reflexes and situational awareness.
Makes a sarcastic joke (‘Michael Jackson wants his gloves back’) to lighten a tense situation

Insists on being let in despite warnings, indicating assertiveness and hands-on involvement.
Relies on his own skills and shows willingness to engage technologically despite being primarily an action-oriented character.
Does not hesitate or panic when facing a skilled digital opponent, maintaining composure.
Orders to shut down the internet to stop the villain despite the massive ramifications, demonstrating decisiveness and trust in his team.
Commands others abruptly ('Shut it down, then'), showing bluntness but a commitment to solving the problem.
Traces the phone call to a specific area code in Lancaster County, showing investigative skill.

Observes the unusual presence of classic muscle cars and quickly realizes they are out of place, prompting immediate tactical action.
Questions others and interprets environmental clues with confidence, showing attentive situational awareness.
Recognizes the gunship's demand to put down weapons as a bluff and confidently orders to keep going.
Grabs Rooney and pulls her down to safety just before the helicopter's rotor blade cuts through, instinctively securing her with the harness buckle.
Hangs out of the open fuselage during the helicopter crash, focused on survival but also on preserving others' safety.
Checks the pilot's vitals and confirms he is dead, then takes the pilot's pistol to proceed.
Responds to Jack G's comment about being lucky to be alive with a curt, unsentimental remark and pushes by him.
Quickly checks the pilot's pistol from the dead man and holsters it, preparing to exit.
Wincing and one-eyed, but still assesses the pilot's vitals and determines he is dead.
Pushes by Jack G after being asked if they want to trade places with the dead pilot, showing mental toughness and confidence.
Examines grenades and picks up an assault rifle, then tosses it to Jack G.
Motions for Jack G to come closer to check the natural gas junction site.
Examines the shrapnel and munitions carefully, picks up an assault rifle and promptly passes it to his companion showing tactical awareness and preparedness.
Identifies the danger of natural gas lines everywhere and the risk of explosions, demonstrating understanding of the broader threat.
Looks left and right cautiously at the Natural Gas Junction with only a broken gate indicating some security issue, showing vigilance and situational awareness.
Asks how the natural gas safety lines 'go' showing an initial question about the problem's details, indicating curiosity or need to understand but also suggesting he is processing new information.
Tells Jack G to not stop to save him and that he won't stop to save Jack G, focusing on completing the mission.
Shoves Jack G clear of incoming gunfire, taking a risky action to protect a comrade.

Tries to steady himself despite injury and keeps fighting.
Intervenes to protect himself and others, fights Lydia aggressively.

Grabs the pipe wrench and uses it effectively in combat, hitting Lydia in her blind spot with calculated, precise blows.
